leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 90] s 90 Judgments generally (cf Act No 52 1970, section 91; Act No 9 1973, section 81)

leg:heading.title: Judgments generally (cf Act No 52 1970, section 91; Act No 9 1973, section 81)

p.text: The court is, at or after trial or otherwise as the nature of the case requires, to give such judgment or make such order as the nature of the case requires.
If there is a claim by a plaintiff and a cross-claim by a defendant, the court:
may give judgment for the balance only of the sums of money awarded on the respective claims, or
may give judgment in respect of each claim,
and may give judgment similarly where several claims arise between plaintiffs, defendants and other parties.

A single judgment may be given in relation to all of the successful party’s claims in the proceedings. If there are multiple proceedings which have been heard together it is technically necessary to enter separate judgments in each proceedings. However, if the proceedings are, or have been formally consolidated, a single judgment may be entered: Dimas v GIO (NSW) (1992) 15 MVR 213; BC9201853 .

level.toc-caption: [s 90.10] Set off of claims, judgments and costs orders

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 90.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 21.

heading.title: Set off of claims, judgments and costs orders

p.text: The power to set off claims generally is dealt with in the notes to CPA s 21 . The power to set off judgments on claims and cross claims is dealt with in [9.10.35] . The power to set off judgments and costs orders is discussed in [s 21.25] .
Legislation cited in [s 90.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 95.

Where two or more defendants are liable for the same damage a successful plaintiff is entitled to enter judgment against each defendant for the full amount of the damages, unless a special order is made: Spicer v Carmody (1948) 48 SR (NSW) 348 ; Speirs v Caledonian Collieries Ltd (1956) SR (NSW) 483 at 512; Barisic v Devenport [1978] 2 NSWLR 111 . See also CPA s 95 in relation to judgment in cases of joint liability.
The nature and extent of the obligation to give reasons is discussed in [36.2.10] .

Sometimes difficult questions arise about the possible impact of taxation on an award of damages. Rather than attempt to resolve these questions on a probability assessment some cases have taken the approach of attempting to preserve the positions of both parties against the contingency of an adverse taxation outcome. These approaches have included reserving further consideration of damages: Sydney Refractive Eye Surgery Centre Pty Ltd v Beaumount [2004] NSWSC 164; BC200401518 ; PM Sulcs & Associates Pty Ltd v Daihatsu Australia Pty Ltd [2001] NSWSC 798; BC200105479 ; requiring an undertaking to refund damages if tax is not adversely assessed: Tuite v Exelby (1993) 93 ATC 4,293; declaring the plaintiff entitled to an indemnity in respect of any subsequent tax determination: Provan v HCL Real Estate Ltd (1992) 92 ATC 4644; 24 ATR 238 ; PM Sulcs & Associates Pty Ltd v Daihatsu Australia Pty Ltd , above.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 91] s 91 Effect of dismissal of proceedings (cf SCR Part 40, rule 8)

leg:heading.title: Effect of dismissal of proceedings (cf SCR Part 40, rule 8)

p.text: Dismissal of:
any proceedings, either generally or in relation to any cause of action, or
the whole or any part of a claim for relief in any proceedings,
does not, subject to the terms on which any order for dismissal was made, prevent the plaintiff from bringing fresh proceedings or claiming the same relief in fresh proceedings.

Despite subsection (1), if, following a determination on the merits in any proceedings, the court dismisses the proceedings, or any claim for relief in the proceedings, the plaintiff is not entitled to claim any relief in respect of the same cause of action in any subsequent proceedings commenced in that or any other court.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 92] s 92 Judgments for possession of land (cf Act No 52 1970, sections 92 and 96(3))

leg:heading.title: Judgments for possession of land (cf Act No 52 1970, sections 92 and 96(3))

p.text: Judgment for possession of land takes the place of, and, subject to the uniform rules, has the same effect as, a judgment for the claimant in ejectment given under the practice of the Supreme Court as it was immediately before 1 July 1972.
1 July 1972 was the date of commencement of the Supreme Court Act 1970.
Legislation cited in [s 92.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 20.
The section complements s 20 of the CPA. The procedural restrictions on the enforcement of a judgment for possession are outlined in [s 20.1] .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 93] s 93 Judgments for detention of goods (cf Act No 52 1970, section 93; Act No 9 1973, section 83; Act No 11 1970, section 28A)

leg:heading.title: Judgments for detention of goods (cf Act No 52 1970, section 93; Act No 9 1973, section 83; Act No 11 1970, section 28A)

p.text: In proceedings for the detention of goods, the court may (whether or not their value has yet been assessed) give judgment:
for their delivery to the plaintiff, or
for payment to the plaintiff of an amount equivalent to their assessed value, or
for their delivery to the plaintiff or for payment to the plaintiff of their assessed value, at the defendant’s option,
and, in addition to any judgment referred to in paragraph (a), (b) or (c), may also give judgment for payment to the plaintiff of damages for their detention.
The court may, in an order for delivery of goods or in a subsequent order, specify the date by which delivery of the goods must be effected.

If judgment has been given as referred to in subsection (1)(a), but the goods are subsequently damaged, destroyed or otherwise rendered unavailable for delivery, the court may, on application by the plaintiff, make an order for the payment to the plaintiff of an amount equivalent to their assessed value, as referred to in subsection (1)(b).

If judgment has been given as referred to in subsection (1)(c) and the plaintiff subsequently applies for an order under this subsection, the court may make an order for the delivery of the goods to the plaintiff without the option for any payment of the kind referred to in subsection (1)(b).
In this section, the assessed value of goods is their value as assessed by, or in accordance with the directions of, the court.

level.toc-caption: [s 93.5] Judgment for the return of goods

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 93.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 93(1) , s 93(1)(a).

heading.title: Judgment for the return of goods

p.text: The three forms of judgment mentioned in s 93(1) broadly reflect those referred to in General and Finance Facilities Ltd v Cooks Cars (Romford) Ltd [1963] 2 All ER 314 at 319; [1963] 1 WLR 644 at 651 per Diplock LJ. A judgment for the specific delivery of the goods ( s 93(1)(a) of the CPA) will usually only be appropriate where they have a special value and monetary damages would not be an adequate remedy: Aristoc Industries Pty Ltd v RA Wenham (Builders) Pty Ltd [1965] NSWR 581 at 587–90 ; Doulton Potteries Ltd v Bronotte [1971] 1 NSWLR 591 ; GE Capital Asset Services & Trading Asia Pacific Pty Ltd v Rocks Excavations & Plant Hire Pty Ltd (2003) 11 BPR 21,253; [2003] NSWSC 99; BC200300584 ; Hymas v Ogden [1905] 1 KB 246 (return of a racing dog). However, if the making of an order would bestow a windfall benefit on the plaintiff it may be appropriate either to refuse the order or to make it conditional upon the plaintiff making an appropriate allowance or payment of compensation: Howard E Perry & Co v British Railways Board [1980] 2 All ER 579 at 585–6; [1980] 1 WLR 1375 ; Greenwood v Bennett [1973] QB 195; [1972] 3 All ER 586 ; Thomas v Robinson [1977] 1 NZLR 385 ; McKeown v Cavalier Yachts Pty Ltd (1988) 13 NSWLR 303 .

level.toc-caption: [s 93.10] Judgment for the value of goods

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 93.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 93(1)(b), s 93(1)(c).

heading.title: Judgment for the value of goods

p.text: A judgment for the value of the goods ( s 93(1)(b) of the CPA) is appropriate where the chattel is an ordinary article and damages are likely to be an adequate remedy: Whitley Ltd v Hilt [1918] 2 KB 808 at 819, 824 . As to time when the value of the goods is to be assessed, see Rosenthal v Alderton & Sons Ltd [1946] 1 KB 374; [1946] 1 All ER 583 . A judgment which gives the defendant the option of returning the chattel ( s 93(1)(c) of the CPA) should specify the assessed value of the chattel and any separate amount determined as damages for their detention. A judgment for the value of the goods does not itself vest the property of the goods in the defendant. But once the defendant has satisfied the judgment, the payment may be considered having been made pursuant to a notional sale of the goods: Brinsmead v Harrison (1872) LR 6 CP 584 at 588; Brinsmead v Harrison (1871) LR 7 CP 547; Ellis v John Stenning & Sons [1932] 2 Ch 81 .

Damages for the value of the goods, and damages for their detention, should be assessed separately: General and Finance Facilities Ltd v Cooks Cars (Romford) Ltd [1963] 2 All ER 314; [1963] 1 WLR 644 ; Strand Electric and Engineering Co Ltd v Brisford Entertainments Ltd [1952] 1 All ER 797 at 801 per Denning LJ. Where the detention continues up to the date of judgment, the plaintiff is entitled to have the value of the goods assessed at the date of judgment rather than at the time of the defendant's refusal to comply with the plaintiff's demand: Rosenthal v Alderton & Sons Ltd [1946] 1 KB 374; [1946] 1 All ER 583 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 94] s 94 Failure to comply with order to execute instrument (cf Act No 52 1970, section 100)

leg:heading.title: Failure to comply with order to execute instrument (cf Act No 52 1970, section 100)

p.text: If any person does not comply with a judgment or order directing the person:
to execute any conveyance, contract or other document, or
to endorse any negotiable instrument,
the court may order that the conveyance, contract or other document be executed, or the negotiable instrument endorsed, by such person as the court may nominate for that purpose.

A conveyance, contract, document or instrument that is executed or endorsed pursuant to an order under subsection (1) operates, and is for all purposes available, as if it had been executed or endorsed by the person originally directed to execute or endorse it.

level.toc-caption: [s 94.5] Failure to comply with order to execute instrument

heading.title: Failure to comply with order to execute instrument

p.text: There is no limitation on the class of document in relation to which the powers accorded by this section may be invoked nor is there any limitation on the purpose for which a document executed in accordance with the powers so accorded may be used: Astro Exito Navegacion SA v Southland Enterprise Co Ltd [1983] 2 AC 787; [1983] 2 All ER 725 at 735; [1983] 3 WLR 130 . Orders should not be made under this section merely because of an anticipated refusal to execute a document. But they may be made if the circumstances demonstrate the probable futility of any proper request: Savage v Norton [1908] 1 Ch 290 at 297 ; Commonwealth Bank of Australia v Gaszewski [2006] NSWSC 772 at [14]; BC200605867 (undefended proceedings — order for execution of mortgage — further order conditioned on proof of non-compliance requiring execution of the mortgage by the registrar); Ciavarella v Polimeni [2008] NSWSC 541; BC200804123 (defendants unlikely to execute transfer — Registrar in Equity or Deputy Registrar authorised to do so); Jeloudev v Lohman [2010] NSWSC 1229; BC201008166 (servient landowner’s consent to development application lodged by person entitled to right of way).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 95] s 95 Joint liability (cf Act No 52 1970, section 97)

p.text: If two or more persons have a joint liability and, in any proceedings, judgment on the liability is given against one or more but not all of them:
the liability of the other or others of them is not discharged by the judgment or by any step taken for the enforcement of the judgment, and

after the judgment takes effect, those of them against whom the judgment is given and the other or others of them become liable, as between those of them against whom the judgment is given on the one hand and the other or the others of them on the other hand, severally but not jointly, and
if there are two or more such persons against whom the judgment is not given, they remain, after the judgment takes effect, jointly liable amongst themselves, and

if the judgment is satisfied wholly or in part by payment or by recovery under execution, the liability of the persons against whom the judgment is not given is taken also to have been satisfied in the amount of the payment or recovery.

This section does not affect a person’s right to contribution or indemnity in respect of the person’s satisfaction, wholly or in part, of a liability that the person has (whether jointly or severally or jointly and severally) with any other person.
This section does not apply to a judgment to which section 5(1)(a) of the Law Reform (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1946 applies.
In this section, liability includes liability in contract, liability in tort and liability under a statute.

level.toc-caption: [s 95.5] Effect of judgment against persons jointly liable

heading.title: Effect of judgment against persons jointly liable

p.text: At common law joint liability, whether in contract or tort, was regarded as “one and indivisible”: Duck v Mayeu [1892] 2 QB 511; [1891–4] All ER Rep 410 ; Thompson v Australian Capital Television Pty Ltd (1996) 186 CLR 574; 141 ALR 1 at 24 per Gummow J. Accordingly, a judgment obtained against any one of several persons who were jointly liable merged the cause of action in the judgment and precluded further proceedings against any of the other persons, even if the judgment was not satisfied: Brinsmead v Harrison (1871) LR 7 CP 547; XL Petroleum (NSW) Pty Ltd v Caltex Oil (Aust) Pty Ltd (1985) 155 CLR 448 at 456; 57 ALR 639 ; Wah Tat Bank Ltd v Chan Cheng Kum [1975] AC 507 at 515 ; see also Kendall v Hamilton (1879) 4 App Cas 504 ; Duck v Mayeu [1892] 2 QB 511 at 513; [1891–4] All ER Rep 410 per AL Smith LJ; Parr v Schnell [1923] 1 KB 1 . Under the present section, judgment may be obtained against any of the persons jointly liable and successive proceedings may be brought against others subject to the prohibition against double recovery.

level.toc-caption: [s 95.10] Form of judgment against persons jointly liable

heading.title: Form of judgment against persons jointly liable

p.text: A successful plaintiff is entitled to enter judgment for the full amount of their proven damages against each defendant who is jointly liable: Spicer v Carmody (1948) 48 SR (NSW) 348 ; Speirs v Caledonian Collieries Ltd (1956) SR (NSW) 483 at 512; Barisic v Devenport [1978] 2 NSWLR 111 .

The section only refers to the effect of a judgment. Historically, a consensual release of a person who was jointly liable was still regarded as discharging any other persons jointly liable: see North v Wakefield (1849) 13 QB 536 at 541; 116 ER 1368 ; Ex parte Good; Re Armitage (1877) 5 Ch D 46 . This explains the use of the “covenant not to sue” as an alternative to a formal release of joint obligees. Such a covenant protected the covenantee from further claims by the principal creditor, but still allowed the creditor to claim against the others jointly liable: Thompson v Australian Capital Television Pty Ltd (1996) 186 CLR 574 at 609; 141 ALR 1 at 26 per Gummow J; Apley Estates Co Ltd v De Bernales [1947] Ch 217 ; Cutler v McPhail [1962] 2 QB 292 at 296 . It also left the covenantee exposed to claims for contribution from those other jointly liable persons: Hutton v Eyre [1814-23] All ER Rep 151; (1815) 128 ER 1046 ; Glanville Williams on Joint Obligations, 1949, para 50. However, these authorities, and the general proposition about the indivisibility of a joint cause of action on which they are based, must now be read in the light of the decision in Thompson v Australian Capital Television Pty Ltd (1996) 186 CLR 574; 141 ALR 1 . There, in a case dealing with joint tortious liability (as to which see [s 97.4] ) the High Court held that contribution legislation such as the Law Reform (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1946 impliedly abrogated the rule that release of one joint tortfeasor released all.

The judgment creditor is not entitled to double recovery. Full payment of damages by one person will preclude any further recovery from others whether they are jointly or severally liable: United Australia Ltd v Barclays Bank Ltd [1941] AC 1 at 20 ; Kohnke v Karger [1951] 2 KB 670 at 674–6 ; Tang Man Sit v Capacious Investments Ltd [1996] AC 514 at 522 ; Ruffino v Grace Bros Pty Ltd [1980] 1 NSWLR 732 . Payments of less than the full judgment debt effect a corresponding reduction in the amount of the liability: Bryantson Finance v de Vries [1975] QB 703 ; Jameson v Central Electricity Generating Board [2000] 1 AC 455 at 472; [1999] 1 All ER 193 ; Castellan v Electric Power Transmission Pty Ltd (1967) 69 SR (NSW) 159 at 180–1 ; Baxter v Obacelo Pty Ltd (2000) 48 NSWLR 522 at 531; [2000] NSWCA 69; BC200001448 . Where payments are made as a result of a compromise of a disputed claim, irrespective of whether the compromise is reflected in a judgment or a mere settlement agreement, difficult questions arise as to whether the payment fully discharges all those liable for the damage to which the disputed claim relates. In Jameson v Central Electricity Generating Board [1998] QB 323 ; Jameson v Central Electricity Generating Board [2000] 1 AC 455 at 474–6; [1999] 1 All ER 193 , the House of Lords held that satisfaction would discharge the other potential tortfeasors if the amount had either been determined, or agreed upon, as the full value of the disputed claim for damages: Jameson v Central Electricity Generating Board [2000] 1 AC 455 at 472; [1999] 1 All ER 193 applied in Baxter v Obacelo Pty Ltd (2000) 48 NSWLR 522; [2000] NSWCA 69; BC200001448 .

level.toc-caption: [s 95.25] Liability in tort — the Law Reform (Miscellaneous Provision) Act 1946

heading.title: Liability in tort — the Law Reform (Miscellaneous Provision) Act 1946

p.text: The present section does not apply to judgments that fall within Law Reform (Miscellaneous Provision) Act 1946 s 5(1)(a). That section abolishes the common law rule that the cause of action against joint tortfeasors merges in a judgment obtained against one of them. Consequently, under the Act separate judgments may be given for damages caused by a joint tort. Damages may be awarded in the same or in different proceedings and the sum awarded by the different judgments need not be the same. In particular, an award of exemplary damages may be made against some only of the joint tortfeasors: XL Petroleum (NSW) Pty Ltd v Caltex Oil (Aust) Pty Ltd (1985) 155 CLR 448; 57 ALR 639 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 96] s 96 Set-off of judgments (cf DCR Part 31, rule 23; Act No 11 1970, section 64)

leg:heading.title: Set-off of judgments (cf DCR Part 31, rule 23; Act No 11 1970, section 64)

p.text: This section applies if, in relation to any two or more judgments of the same court, the judgment creditor and judgment debtor under one or more of the judgments are the judgment debtor and judgment creditor, respectively, under the other judgments.

The judgment debtor under any such judgment (the first judgment) may apply to the court for an order that the judgment be set off against any other such judgment (the second judgment) in respect of which he or she is the judgment creditor.
An order under this section has the following effect:

if the amount of the first judgment is less than the amount of the second judgment, the first judgment is taken to have been satisfied and the amount of the second judgment is taken to have been reduced by the amount of the first judgment,
if the amount of the first judgment is equal to the amount of the second judgment, both judgments are taken to have been satisfied,

if the amount of the first judgment is greater than the amount of the second judgment, the second judgment is taken to have been satisfied and the amount of the first judgment is taken to have been reduced by the amount of the second judgment.
[subs (4) rep Act 94 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1.12[23], effective 6 July 2009]
This section does not apply to judgments of the Supreme Court.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 97] s 97 Arrest warrants (cf SCR Part 42, rule 7)

p.text: Subject to rules of court:
if, by subpoena or otherwise, the court makes an order, whether under this Act or any other law:
for a person to attend court for any purpose, or
for a person to produce any document or thing to the court, and
the person fails to comply with the order,
the court may issue, or make an order for the issue of, a warrant for the person’s arrest.
[subs (1) am Act 56 of 2006 s 3 and Sch 1[4], effective 20 June 2006]
Subject to rules of court, an arrest warrant may be issued without notice to the person.
The court from which an arrest warrant has been issued may revoke the warrant.

An arrest warrant is sufficient authority for any person to whom it is addressed, with the assistance of such police officers as may be necessary, to arrest the person named in the warrant, to convey the person to the place specified in the warrant and to deliver the person into the custody of the court sitting at that place.
Legislation cited in [s 97.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 UCPR r 38.1, UCPR r 38.6, r 38.6(3).

A warrant issued under the present section must be limited to expire within 3 months and may be revoked at any time: UCPR r 38.6 . Where the default is a failure to attend in compliance with an order for examination (under UCPR r 38.1 ) a warrant cannot be issued unless the proposed examinee has been served with notice in accordance with UCPR r 38.6(3) . The approved form for the issue of a warrant is Form 57 ‘Notice of motion — Arrest warrant for examination’. Form 65 is the approved form for an arrest warrant.
Legislation cited in [s 97.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 36.1, r 38.6(c), r 42.27.

The power to issue a warrant for a person’s arrest may be exercised without specific notice (unless it relates to an order for examination — see UCPR r 38.6(c) but only where the person has already failed to comply with a prior order. A person will not have “failed to comply” with an order unless they have been given written notice. And typically the form of any order will in fact give notice of the person’s liability to arrest if they fail to comply (see eg UCPR Form 27 ‘Subpoena to Attend to Give Evidence’). The power to make an order requiring a person’s attendance to answer a charge of contempt is well established: see Attorney-General v Hayden (1994) 34 NSWLR 638 ; Registrar, Court of Appeal v Ritter (1985) 34 NSWLR 641 ; Mirembe Pty Ltd v Dangar [2009] NSWSC 94; BC200901055 (failure to comply with order to attend court, arrest warrant issued, execution stayed, liberty to the defendant to apply to vary or discharge the order). Apart from the explicit power conferred by the present section, the arrest power can be derived from UCPR r 36.1 (Ritter at 652–3 per McHugh JA), or it is an inherent power recognised by UCPR r 42.27 (Ritter at 651 per Priestley JA, at 653 per McHugh): Travener v Ussfeller [2006] NSWSC 807; BC200606256 at [14] (order made requiring attendance to answer contempt charges).
